title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: JOUR479X Class Blog
text:
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.2     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors



logs_24 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs24.csv")

Rows: 1717 Columns: 79
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (11): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, Bowl.x, TeamURL, Outcome, Bowl.y,...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

logs_25 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs25.csv")

Rows: 711 Columns: 77
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (9): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Conferenc...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.



bigtenplays_24 <- logs_24 |> filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference") |> group_by(Team) |> mutate(AveragePlays = mean(TotalPlays)) |>  select(AveragePlays, TotalPlays, Team)

bigtenplays_25 <- logs_25 |> filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference") |> group_by(Team) |> mutate(AveragePlays = mean(TotalPlays)) |>  select(AveragePlays, TotalPlays, Team)


ggplot() +
  geom_bar(
    data = bigtenplays_24,
    aes(
      x = reorder(Team, AveragePlays),
      weight = AveragePlays
          )) +
      labs(
        title = "2024-25 Big Ten Teams By Number of Offensive Plays",
        x = "School",
        y = "Average Offensive Plays per Game"
      ) +
  theme_light() +
  coord_flip()









ggplot() +
  geom_bar(
    data = bigtenplays_25,
    aes(
      x = reorder(Team, AveragePlays),
      weight = AveragePlays
          )) +
      labs(
        title = "2025-26 Big Ten Teams By Number of Offensive Plays",
        x = "School",
        y = "Average Offensive Plays per Game"
      ) +
  theme_light() +
  coord_flip()

title: Big Ten Football Average Plays Season-To-Season
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.2     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors




Code
logs_24 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs24.csv")


Rows: 1717 Columns: 79
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (11): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, Bowl.x, TeamURL, Outcome, Bowl.y,...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
logs_25 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs25.csv")


Rows: 711 Columns: 77
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (9): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Conferenc...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.




Code
bigtenplays_24 <- logs_24 |> filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference") |> group_by(Team) |> summarise(AveragePlays = mean(TotalPlays))

bigtenplays_25 <- logs_25 |> filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference") |> group_by(Team) |> summarise(AveragePlays = mean(TotalPlays))


In this chunk, I’m filtering the data, which includes all college football games involving FBS teams, to only include games played by teams in the Big Ten. I then group the data by team so that my subsequent mutation, adding the average number of offensive plays the team ran per game, applies to each team individually and not the entire dataset.
I then selected AveragePlays, TotalPlays, and Team to simplify my dataset and make it only include those three columns.


Code
ggplot() +
  geom_bar(
    data = bigtenplays_24,
    aes(
      x = reorder(Team, AveragePlays),
      weight = AveragePlays
          )) +
      labs(
        title = "2024-25 Big Ten Teams By Number of Offensive Plays",
        x = "School",
        y = "Average Offensive Plays per Game"
      ) +
  theme_light() +
  coord_flip()









This data reflects time of possession, yards per play (somewhat), and other factors, but it more so displays the tempo each team’s offense plays with. The numbers certainly don’t reflect the quality of a team because Maryland, Rutgers, and USC - the top three teams in average offensive plays per game - played to an 18-20 record in the 2024-25 season.


Code
ggplot() +
  geom_bar(
    data = bigtenplays_25,
    aes(
      x = reorder(Team, AveragePlays),
      weight = AveragePlays
          )) +
      labs(
        title = "2025-26 Big Ten Teams By Number of Offensive Plays",
        x = "School",
        y = "Average Offensive Plays per Game"
      ) +
  theme_light() +
  coord_flip()









The following season, Rutgers, Maryland, and Nebraska remained in the top five by average offensive plays per game, though there were some significant changes at the bottom and middle of the dataset. Purdue went from last in 2024-25 to third in 2025-26 so far. Indiana went from middle of the pack last season to second so far this season.
Ohio State, interestingly, has remained near the bottom of the conference, despite being the Big Ten’s premier team in both seasons. Illinois and UCLA have also stayed near the bottom in offensive plays per game.

title: Post With Code
text: This is a post with executable code.

title: How Does Maryland Volleyball Score Its Points?
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(waffle)




Code
matches_2025 <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dwillis/NCAAWomensVolleyballData/main/data/ncaa_womens_volleyball_matchstats_2025.csv")


Rows: 4878 Columns: 38
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (4): team, opponent, home_away, result
dbl  (33): ncaa_id, team_score, opponent_score, s, kills, errors, total_atta...
date  (1): date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


This dataset contains thousands of match logs from across the current Division I collegiate volleyball season. Since I’ll only be analyzing Maryland right now, I need to filter the data to only include Maryland’s matches.


Code
mdmatches_2025 <- matches_2025 |> filter(team == "Maryland")


Now, I need to calculate the total number of kills, blocks, aces, and opponent errors (four methods of scoring points) that Maryland has amassed this season.


Code
mdmatches_2025 |> group_by(team) |> summarise(
  total_kills = sum(kills),
  total_blocks = sum(block_solos + block_assists),
  total_aces = sum(aces),
  total_opp_errors = sum(defensive_errors)
)


# A tibble: 1 × 5
  team     total_kills total_blocks total_aces total_opp_errors
  <chr>          <dbl>        <dbl>      <dbl>            <dbl>
1 Maryland         525          216         72              257


To visualize the proportionality of a statistic - that is, how much a smaller datapoint (such as kills, in this case) accounts for a larger stat (such as points) - waffle charts work well. Here I’ll create one that cleanly and simply displays how Maryland scores its points.


Code
md <- c("Kills"=525, "Blocks"=216, "Aces"=72, "Opponent Errors"=257)




Code
waffle(
 md/2,
 rows = 10,
 title = "Maryland Volleyball's Points",
 xlab = "1 square = 1 point",
colors = c("red", "black","gold","grey") 
)


Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.
ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the waffle package.
  Please report the issue to the authors.









As is the case for most volleyball teams, a majority of Maryland’s points come from kills or opponent errors. This data in itself isn’t too useful without context, though. To better gauge how the Terps’ scoring stacks up to other teams, we need to analyze another team.
I’ll choose Nebraska to take a look at the scoring breakdown for one of the nation’s premier programs.


Code
neb_matches_2025 <- matches_2025 |> filter(team == "Nebraska")




Code
neb_matches_2025 |> group_by(team) |> summarise(
  total_kills = sum(kills),
  total_blocks = sum(block_solos + block_assists),
  total_aces = sum(aces),
  total_opp_errors = sum(defensive_errors)
)


# A tibble: 1 × 5
  team     total_kills total_blocks total_aces total_opp_errors
  <chr>          <dbl>        <dbl>      <dbl>            <dbl>
1 Nebraska         777          258         60              325




Code
neb <- c("Kills"=777, "Blocks"=258, "Aces"=60, "Opponent Errors"=325)




Code
waffle(
 neb/3,
 rows = 10,
 title = "Nebraska Volleyball's Points",
 xlab = "1 square = 1 point",
colors = c("red", "black","grey","tan") 
)









Since Nebraska has considerably more points than Maryland, I’ll need to add “padding” to Maryland’s points total to ensure that each waffle chart is displaying data on the same scale. Otherwise, each waffle chart would display different-sized squares.
Since Nebraska’s points total is 1,420 and Maryland’s is 1,070, I’ll add 350 squares of padding. To do this, I’ll add a set of 350 unnamed squares to the waffle chart.


Code
md <- c("Kills"=525, "Blocks"=216, "Aces"=72, "Opponent Errors"=257, 350)




Code
iron(
waffle(
 md/3,
 rows = 10,
 title = "Maryland Volleyball's Points",
 xlab = "1 square = 1 point",
colors = c("red", "black","gold","grey", "white") 
),
waffle(
 neb/3,
 rows = 10,
 title = "Nebraska Volleyball's Points",
 xlab = "1 square = 1 point",
colors = c("red", "black","grey","tan") 
))









Kills, blocks, aces, and opponent errors account for roughly the same share of both teams’ total points. Nebraska seems to accumulate slightly more of its points from kills, and maybe a bit more from opponent errors, compared to Maryland, but aside from that, the proportionality of all four stats is largely the same.
The share of these stats may not be the most indicative of how good a team is overall, but rather how proficient the team is in a specific area. If a team had a considerable share of its points from blocks, for example, that would show that they likely have a sturdy defense.
I would have to create and analyze waffle charts for other teams to determine how Maryland and Nebraska’s share of statistics are typical, or if they both differ from the average. I’d imagine that the most significant variation comes from the number of blocks and aces a team has tallied, because most of a team’s points will naturally come from kills and opponent errors.

title: Maryland’s Decision to Run the Ball on Third and Six Wasn’t All That Weird
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(cfbfastR)




Code
cfblogs <- load_cfb_pbp(year = 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024, 2025)




Code
third_and_six <- cfblogs |> filter(down == 3) |> filter(distance == 6)

third_and_six_passes <- third_and_six |> filter(play_type =="Pass Reception" | play_type =="Pass Incompletion" | play_type =="Passing Touchdown" | play_type =="Interception Return" | play_type =="Interception Return Touchdown")




Code
third_and_six_runs <- third_and_six |> filter(play_type == "Rush" | play_type=="Rushing Touchdown")


There were 3,695 third and six plays. 798 of them were runs, meaning approximately 21.6 percent of the time, teams ran the ball on third and six.


Code
third_and_six_runs_yards <- third_and_six_runs |> summarise(AverageYards = mean(yards_gained))




Code
third_and_six_runs_frequency <- third_and_six_runs |> group_by(pos_team) |> summarise(Runs = sum(play_type =="Rush" | play_type =="Rushing Touchdown"))




Code
maryland_third_and_six_runs <- third_and_six_runs |> filter(pos_team == "Maryland")

title: Winning Football Games is Tough. Rushing for Fewer than 100 Yards Makes it Much Tougher
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(lubridate)

logs <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs1525.csv")


Rows: 17133 Columns: 79
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (11): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, Bowl.x, TeamURL, Outcome, Bowl.y,...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
# the Season is the year of the game, except when the game is in January. Then it's year-1

logs <- logs |> mutate(Season = case_when(
  month(Date) == 1 ~ year(Date) - 1,
  .default = year(Date)
))

season_games <- logs |> 
  group_by(Season) |> 
  summarise(all_games = n())

season_games_under_100_wins <- logs |> 
  filter(Result == "W", RushYds < 100) |> 
  group_by(Season) |> 
  summarise(low_rush_wins = n())

combined_games <- season_games |> 
  inner_join(season_games_under_100_wins, join_by(Season)) |> 
  mutate(pct_low_rush_wins = low_rush_wins/all_games * 100)


##Big Ten Teams


Code
big_ten_season_games <- logs |> filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference") |> group_by(Season) |> summarise(big_ten_games=n())

big_ten_season_games_under_100_wins <- logs |> 
  filter(Result == "W", RushYds < 100) |> filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference") |> 
  group_by(Season) |> 
  summarise(big_ten_low_rush_wins = n())

bigten_combined_games <- big_ten_season_games |> inner_join(big_ten_season_games_under_100_wins, join_by(Season)) |> mutate(pct_lowrush_bigten_wins = big_ten_low_rush_wins/big_ten_games * 100)

combined_games_w_bigten <- combined_games |> 
  inner_join(bigten_combined_games, join_by(Season))




Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data = combined_games_w_bigten, aes(x = Season, y = pct_low_rush_wins), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data = combined_games_w_bigten, aes(x = Season, y = pct_lowrush_bigten_wins), color="blue") + 
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = ~ axisTicks(., log = FALSE)) +
  labs(
    title = "Big Ten Teams with Low Rushing Yards in a Game Have Struggled",
    subtitle = "In games with <100 rushing yards",
    y = "Percent of Wins"
  )









Running the ball effectively is usually an easy way to control the pace of a game and coast to a win. Rushing for fewer than 100 yards is not.
Across all college football games since 2015, a slim percentage of games - usually less than 6% - resulted in a team with fewer than 100 rushing yards winning. The Big Ten had a bit more variance during that stretch.
In 2021, 10.5% of games saw the winning team fall short of the 100-rushing-yards mark. The percentage for all 1,659 games across every conference that year was 6.3%.
Five years earlier, however, only four of the 180 Big Ten games (2.2%) featured the victorious team amassing fewer than 100 rushing yards, which was lower than the national mark of 3.1%.
This sparks a question about how the passing game of Big Ten teams have changed during this span. In years where the percentage of teams that won with low rushing yards totals is lower, is the average passing yards also lower (meaning the passing game couldn’t compensate for the running game’s deficiencies)?

title: Maryland football’s efficiency has been average at best in the past decade
text:
Maryland football has been seen as one of the nation’s weaker programs in recent years. The statistics support that notion.
Since 2015, the Terps’ offensive and defensive yards per play has been mediocre at best. Most of their single0game performances in these metrics are below the national average - roughly five yards per play gained on offense and five yards per play allowed on defense.


Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors




Code
logs <- read_csv("https://thescoop.org/sports-data-files/footballlogs1525.csv")


Rows: 17240 Columns: 80
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (11): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, Bowl.x, TeamURL, Outcome, Bowl.y,...
dbl  (65): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.




Code
winlosslogs <- logs |> 
  mutate(
    wins = case_when(
      grepl("W", Outcome) ~ 1, 
      grepl("L", Outcome) ~ 0)
)




Code
winlosslogs |> 
  group_by(Team, Conference, Season) |>
  mutate(
    OffensiveYPP = TotalYds/TotalPlays, 
    DefensiveYPP = DefTotalYds/DefTotalPlays) -> ypp




Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=ypp, aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP)
    )


Warning: Removed 1 row containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_point()`).











Code
maryland <- ypp |> filter(Team == "Maryland")

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=ypp, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP), 
    color="grey", 
    alpha=.5) + 
  geom_point(
    data=maryland, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP), 
    color="red")


Warning: Removed 1 row containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_point()`).









Here I created a new dataset including only Maryland’s game since 2015, and highlighted those games in red.


Code
ypp |> 
  ungroup() |> 
  summarise(
    offense = mean(OffensiveYPP), 
    defense = mean(DefensiveYPP)
    )


# A tibble: 1 × 2
  offense defense
    <dbl>   <dbl>
1    5.79     NaN


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=ypp, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP), 
    color="grey", 
    alpha=.5) + 
  geom_point(
    data=maryland, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP), 
    color="red") + 
  geom_vline(xintercept = 5.811255) + 
  geom_hline(yintercept = 5.562701)


Warning: Removed 1 row containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_point()`).









This block of code adds a horizontal and vertical line to represent the average offensive and defensive yards per play for every team since 2015. This allows better illustrates where Maryland stands relative to the rest of the country.


Code
ypp |> 
  ungroup() |> 
  summarise(
    offense = mean(OffensiveYPP), 
    defense = mean(DefensiveYPP)
    )


# A tibble: 1 × 2
  offense defense
    <dbl>   <dbl>
1    5.79     NaN


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=ypp, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP), 
    color="grey", 
    alpha=.5) + 
  geom_point(
    data=maryland, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP), 
    color="red") + 
  geom_vline(xintercept = 5.811255) + 
  geom_hline(yintercept = 5.562701) +
  labs(
    title = "Maryland's Mediocrity",
    subtitle = "The Terps' single-game offensive and defensive yards per play have been unimpressive for much of\nthe past decade", caption="Source: NCAA | By Trevor Gomes")  + theme_minimal() + 
     theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    )


Warning: Removed 1 row containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_point()`).

Code
library(janitor)



Attaching package: 'janitor'

The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    chisq.test, fisher.test


Code
library(ggbeeswarm)


Warning: package 'ggbeeswarm' was built under R version 4.5.2


Code
library(ggrepel)


Warning: package 'ggrepel' was built under R version 4.5.2


Code
set.seed(1234)




Code
soccer_logs <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dwillis/NCAAWomensSoccerData/refs/heads/main/data/ncaa_mens_soccer_playerstats_2025.csv") |> clean_names()


Rows: 5250 Columns: 24
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (7): team, full_name, roster_name, first_name, last_name, yr, pos
dbl (16): season, team_id, number, ht, gp, gs, goals, assists, sh_att, so_g,...
lgl  (1): corners

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.




Code
soccer_logs <- soccer_logs |> filter(so_g > 5)




Code
ggplot() + geom_beeswarm(data = soccer_logs, aes(x= yr, y = so_g), color="grey")











Code
umd <- soccer_logs |> filter(team == "Maryland Terrapins, Terps")




Code
ggplot() + geom_beeswarm(
  data = soccer_logs, 
  aes(x= yr, y = so_g), 
  color="grey") + 
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=umd, 
    aes(x= yr, y= so_g), color="red")











Code
vermont <- soccer_logs |> filter(team == "Vermont Catamounts")
princeton <- soccer_logs |> filter(team == "Princeton Tigers")
virginia <- soccer_logs |> filter(team == "Virginia Cavaliers")
bryant <- soccer_logs |> filter(team == "Bryant Bulldogs")




Code
ggplot() + geom_beeswarm(
  data = soccer_logs, 
  aes(x= yr, y = so_g), 
  color="grey") + 
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=umd, 
    aes(x= yr, y= so_g), color="red") +
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=vermont, 
    aes(x= yr, y= so_g), color="green") +
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=princeton, 
    aes(x= yr, y= so_g), color="black") +
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=virginia, 
    aes(x= yr, y= so_g), color="orange")









Unsurprisingly, most high-volume shooters are seniors, which makes intuitive sense because they’re most likely the best and most trusted players on their team. The top four teams in the nation by RPI – Maryland, Vermont, Princeton, and Virginia – especially feature seniors in their offenses. This may be a coaching decision, a product of how many seniors these teams have, or simply because these seniors are getting the most touches.
An interesting detail in this plot is the noticable increase from juniors to seniors. There are markedly more seniors that have recorded over 15 shots on goal this season than juniors. A year of collegiate experience can certainly make a profound difference, but it’s a bit surprising that the jump from junior to senior is that pronounced. The increase from freshmen to sophomores is also noteworthy because it illustrates how formative a player’s first collegiate season is. Few freshmen are trusted enough to attempt a high number of shots on goal, but after they notch a year’s worth of collegiate experience, they’re incorporated into the offense more.

title: Efficient run games fuel some of the Big Ten’s best football teams
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0

✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors




Code
logs <- read_csv("https://www.thescoop.org/sports-data-files/footballlogs25.csv")


Rows: 1255 Columns: 77
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (9): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Conferenc...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.




Code
bigtenlogs <- logs |> filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference")




Code
ggplot() +
  geom_line(data = bigtenlogs, aes(x = Date, y = RushYA))











Code
ggplot() +
  geom_line(data = bigtenlogs, aes(x = Date, y = RushYA, group = Team)) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 12)) +
  facet_wrap(~Team)











Code
bigten_avg <- bigtenlogs |> summarise(avg_ya = mean(RushYA)) |> pull(avg_ya)

ggplot() +
  geom_hline(yintercept = bigten_avg, color = "blue") +
  geom_line(data = bigtenlogs, aes(x = Date, y = RushYA, group = Team)) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 12)) +
  facet_wrap(~Team)









Maryland’s yards per carry has largely been below the Big Ten average of 4.46, even against its three nonconference opponents to start the year. The lone outlier is its most recent game against Rutgers, where the Terps rushed for over 10 yards per attempt. Aside from that game, though, Maryland’s yards per carry has loomed around four or below.
The metric is fairly indicative of team success across the Big Ten. Indiana, Michigan, Oregon and USC - some of the conference’s best teams – have consistently rushed for more than the Big Ten average. Ohio State is somewhat of an anomaly because, despite being the No. 1 team in the nation, its run game has been about average relative to the rest of the conference. Illinois and Washington are interesting cases because they have some of the conference’s least efficient rushing performances by yards per carry, but are still solid teams. Analyzing those performances would be an intriguing next step to take with this story.

title: Buzz Williams preaches rebounding and free throws. Maryland has delivered mixed results
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(ggplot2)




Code
logs <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dwillis/dwillis.github.io/main/docs/sports-data-files/cbblogs1526.csv")


Rows: 111554 Columns: 58
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (8): Season, Opponent, HomeAway, W_L, URL, Conference, Team, OT
dbl  (49): Game, TeamScore, OpponentScore, TeamFG, TeamFGA, TeamFGPCT, Team3...
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.




Code
mdlogs <- logs |> filter(Team == "Maryland")

earlyseasonmdlogs <- mdlogs |> filter(Game > 0, Game < 9)




Code
earlyseasonmdlogs <- earlyseasonmdlogs |> mutate(
  pointdiff = TeamScore - OpponentScore,
  rebounddiff = TeamTotalRebounds - OpponentTotalRebounds,
  freethrowdiff = TeamFTA - OpponentFTA
) 

difflogs <- earlyseasonmdlogs |> group_by(Season) |> summarise(
  meanpointdiff = mean(pointdiff),
  meanrebounddiff = mean(rebounddiff),
  meanfreethrowdiff = mean(freethrowdiff)
  )




Code
ggplot() +
  geom_line(data = difflogs, aes(x = Season, y = meanpointdiff, group = 1)) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 30)) +
  labs(
    y = "Point Differential",
    title = "Maryland's Early-Season Point Differential has Wavered",
    subtitle = "The Terps' point differential through their first eight games has varied from less than three to almost 30"
  )











Code
ggplot() +
  geom_line(data = difflogs, aes(x = Season, y = meanrebounddiff, group = 1)) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(-1, 15)) +
  labs(
    y = "Rebound Differential",
    title = "Maryland Truly is 'Beyond Bad' at Rebounding This Season",
    subtitle = "Much to Buzz Williams' dismay, the Terps are having one of their worst rebounding starts to a season \nin the past decade"
  )











Code
ggplot() +
  geom_line(data = difflogs, aes(x = Season, y = meanfreethrowdiff, group = 1)) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 14)) +
  labs(
    y = "Free Throw Differential",
    title = "Maryland Has Sparked Its Offense From the Free-Throw Line",
    subtitle = "The Terps have posted their highest early-season free throw differential since the 2017-18 season"
  )









Though a sample size of four games is quite limited (so the results should be taken with a grain of salt) it’s worth comparing a few metrics to Maryland’s early-season performances in other years. I chose to define “early-season” as the first eight games of a season because that usually encompasses most or all of non-conference play. The metrics I chose to analyze are point differential (a solid indicator of general team success, on both sides of the floor), rebound differential, and free throw differential (two of Buzz’s points of emphasis for the team this season).
Maryland’s point differential is mediocre compared to its results since 2016. This could be attributed to the limited sample size, however, and the fact that Maryland has played Big East opponents in two of its first four games. Other years’ point differentials may also be skewed by extreme blowouts, such as the 2024-25 squad’s 71-point win over Canisius.
In my opinion, the worthwhile story comes from the rebound differential and free throw differential. Buzz has derided the team’s rebounding this year, and the numbers support that. Maryland has a slim average rebounding advantage of 2.75 this season, its second-lowest in the last 10 seasons. This is especially surprising considering that Buzz Williams-coached teams in the past have excelled in rebounding. Last year’s Texas A&M team was one of the nation’s best rebounding teams.
Buzz has also spoken about how Maryland has had to shoot free throws this year to sustain its offense, which the statistics also show. On average, the Terps have shot nine more free throws than their opponents this season – their second-highest mark in the past decade.

title: Buzz Williams’ teams have emphasized free-throw shooting, owning the glass

Code
logs <- read_csv("https://thescoop.org/sports-data-files/cbblogs1526.csv")

Code
vtlogs <- logs |> filter(Team == "Virginia Tech")
amlogs <- logs |> filter(Team == "Texas A&M")




Code
amavglogs <- amlogs |> group_by(Season) |> summarise(
  reboundspergame = mean(TeamTotalRebounds),
  offreboundspergame = mean(TeamOffRebounds),
  freethrowspergame = mean(TeamFTA),
  pointspergame = mean(TeamScore)
)




Code
vtavglogs <- vtlogs |> group_by(Season) |> summarise(
  reboundspergame = mean(TeamTotalRebounds),
  offreboundspergame = mean(TeamOffRebounds),
  freethrowspergame = mean(TeamFTA),
  pointspergame = mean(TeamScore)
)




Code
mdlogs <- logs |> filter(Team == "Maryland")

mdavglogs <- mdlogs |> group_by(Season) |> summarise(
  reboundspergame = mean(TeamTotalRebounds),
  offreboundspergame = mean(TeamOffRebounds),
  freethrowspergame = mean(TeamFTA),
  pointspergame = mean(TeamScore)
)




Code
natlaveragelogs <- logs |> filter(!(Season == "<<<<<<< HEAD")) |> group_by(Season) |> summarise(
  reboundspergame = mean(TeamTotalRebounds),
  offreboundspergame = mean(TeamOffRebounds),
  freethrowspergame = mean(TeamFTA),
  pointspergame = mean(TeamScore)
)




Code
ggplot() +
geom_line(data = amavglogs, aes(x = Season, y = reboundspergame, group = 1), color = "maroon") +
geom_line(data = vtavglogs, aes(x = Season, y = reboundspergame, group = 1), color = "orange") +
geom_line(data = mdavglogs, aes(x = Season, y = reboundspergame, group = 1), color = "red") +
geom_line(data = natlaveragelogs, aes(x = Season, y = reboundspergame, group = 1), color = "black") +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 40))











Code
ggplot() +
geom_line(data = amavglogs, aes(x = Season, y = offreboundspergame, group = 1), color = "maroon") +
geom_line(data = vtavglogs, aes(x = Season, y = offreboundspergame, group = 1), color = "orange") +
  geom_line(data = mdavglogs, aes(x = Season, y = offreboundspergame, group = 1), color = "red") +
geom_line(data = natlaveragelogs, aes(x = Season, y = offreboundspergame, group = 1), color = "black") +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 16))











Code
ggplot() +
geom_line(data = amavglogs, aes(x = Season, y = freethrowspergame, group = 1), color = "maroon") +
geom_line(data = vtavglogs, aes(x = Season, y = freethrowspergame, group = 1), color = "orange") +
geom_line(data = mdavglogs, aes(x = Season, y = freethrowspergame, group = 1), color = "red") +
geom_line(data = natlaveragelogs, aes(x = Season, y = freethrowspergame, group = 1), color = "black") +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 35))











Code
ggplot() +
geom_line(data = amavglogs, aes(x = Season, y = pointspergame, group = 1), color = "maroon") +
geom_line(data = vtavglogs, aes(x = Season, y = pointspergame, group = 1), color = "orange") +
geom_line(data = mdavglogs, aes(x = Season, y = pointspergame, group = 1), color = "red") +
geom_line(data = natlaveragelogs, aes(x = Season, y = pointspergame, group = 1), color = "black") +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 100))









Buzz Williams has preached rebounding and drawing fouls this season. During his time at Virginia Tech, his teams were surprisingly far below the national average in rebounds and offensive rebounds per game, though that trend changed drastically when he took over Texas A&M in 2019. Williams’ teams in College Station were among the best offensive rebounding units in the country, and were mostly above average in rebounding during his tenure.
In the two years prior to Williams’ arrival, Maryland was a roughly average rebounding team. Though it’s early in the season, they’ve been worse this year than in those two years. The Terps’ rebounding and offensive rebounding have been weaknesses so far this year (much to Buzz’s dismay).
Williams’ teams have been consistently great at drawing contact, however. Save for his final year with Virginia Tech, the Hokies under Buzz Williams took considerably more free throws than average. Williams’ teams in his final three years with Texas A&M were especially prolific from the free-throw line. Maryland was also above average in free throws per game in the two years before Buzz’s arrival, but this year, they’ve shot about 10 more free throws than the national average.
Williams’ teams have been slightly above average from a scoring standpoints. During his days at Virginia Tech, the team was above average in points per game from 2015-16 to 2018-19, and in Texas A&M, they were even closer to the national average. Maryland is averaging its highest points per game in the past decade so far this season, though the limited sample size is skewing that number. The team’s offense will be truly evaluated when they enter conference play,

title: The Wizards’ young lineups aren’t contributing to winning. The franchise doesn’t seem to care
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(hoopR)


Warning: package 'hoopR' was built under R version 4.5.2


Code
library(cowplot)


Warning: package 'cowplot' was built under R version 4.5.2



Attaching package: 'cowplot'

The following object is masked from 'package:lubridate':

    stamp




Code
team_id <- 1610612764
lineups <- nba_leaguedashlineups(team_id = team_id)
wizards <- lineups[1]
wizards <- lineups[[1]]
View(wizards)




Code
wizards <- wizards |> mutate(across(c(6:58), as.numeric))




Code
positivewizlineups <- wizards |> filter(PLUS_MINUS > 0) |> top_n(3, wt = MIN) |> arrange(desc(MIN))
negativewizlineups <- wizards |> filter(PLUS_MINUS < 0) |> top_n(3, wt = MIN) |> arrange(desc(MIN))




Code
positive_bar <- ggplot() +
  geom_bar(
    data = positivewizlineups,
    aes (x = PLUS_MINUS, weight = `MIN`)
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "Coach Brian Keefe and the Wizards Do",
    subtitle = "Wizards lineups with a negative plus/minus",
    x = "Plus/Minus",
    y = "Minutes"
  )




Code
negative_bar <- ggplot() +
  geom_bar(
    data = negativewizlineups,
    aes (x = PLUS_MINUS, weight = `MIN`)
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "Not Care About Winning (Apparently)",
    subtitles = "have played considerably more minutes",
    x = "Plus/Minus",
    y = "Minutes"
  )




Code
plot_grid(positive_bar, negative_bar)


Ignoring unknown labels:
• subtitles : "have played considerably more minutes"









The main takeaway I had from my analysis of the most-played Wizards lineups with a positive plus/minus and a negative plus/minus is that the Wizards are (understandably) committed to giving their young core substantial playing time. Some combination of Bub Carrington, Kyshawn George, Alex Sarr, Tre Johnson, and Cam Whitmore appear in all three of the lowest plus/minus lineups. Despite the wretchedly poor plus/minus, Brian Keefe and company have played those lineups more than the top three positive lineups. Khris Middleton and CJ McCollum, the team’s two most accomplished veterans, are featured in all three of the Wizards’ most positive lineups.
